Fields.DialogueText: Minasan, junbi shite kudasai. A battle is upon us.
@BATTLE
There you are, Kami of the Fleet. I admired your performance earlier.
With the battle or the tsuzumi?
Both were impressive.
I'm glad you approved, Kanchou.
Would you like to share a meal with me? I'd like to finally get to talk to you.
Are we not talking now?

Fields.MenuText: I want to get to know you.
Yes, but in a professional setting.
It's not what I had in mind.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh... very well. I will meet you soon.
We are professionals, nonetheless. But I accept your offer.
I understand. Then, we will feast together.
Excellent! I'll see you soon!
Kamikaze, we still haven't...
With all due respect, Kanchou, please don't interrupt me while I'm preparing for battle.
My apologies, I just happened to be passing through and thought...
Ii desu. I shall see you later. We have Morganas headed this way.
@BATTLE
You wanted to see me, Kanchou?
Yes, I thought it was time we had that meal. And congratulations on another victory today!
Arigatō gozaimasu, Kanchou.
You're welcome.
So...
Yes?
Is there anything you'd like to talk about?
You were the one who invited me here, if I recall correctly.

Fields.MenuText: What are some of your hobbies?
Do you enjoy battles?
How does it feel to be Destroyer No. 1?

Fields.DialogueText: Playing tsuzumi and writing poetry.
I am willing to die for Nippon.
It’s an immense responsibility. I see myself as a role model to the other Belles.
That's...
Would you mind if we spoke in Japanese? Western languages don't thrill me.
... Very well.
Ammunition is to be stored in the correct vessels using the correct organization. Do I make myself clear?
Kamikaze, what are you doing?
The crew haven't been storing the ammunition properly, which affects their speed in preparing for battle.
Such orders really are my responsibility.
Dame desu. I am this vessel.
But I am its commanding officer.
Would you like me to clarify anything?
No, Kanchou. Should I not bring this up to them, then?

Fields.MenuText: As long as you're not rude about it, it shouldn't be a problem.
I would prefer if you came to me first.
You tell me and only me.

Fields.DialogueText: Very well. Thank you, Kanchou.
I will take that into consideration in the future.
... Yes, Kanchou.
Now, prepare for battle!
Hai! Fukoku kyōhei!
@BATTLE
A battle is upon us.
@BATTLE
Shitsurei shimasu. May I have a report on this battle, Kanchou?
You were stellar, per usual.
Is that all?
I noticed the torpedoes were aligned in storage to the millimeter. You obviously have a talent for organization.
Lack of order can result in small mistakes which could lead to our demise.

Fields.MenuText: You don't have to be so paranoid.
I agree. Good work.
Let me know if you need assistance in the future.

Fields.DialogueText: I think war justifies my mentality, Kanchou.
Thank you, Kanchou!
I appreciate your offer.
Well, in the meantime, you've earned plenty of rest. The crew have shōchū in the mess hall.
I would enjoy some. Dōmo, Kanchou.
A battle is upon us.
@BATTLE
Konnichiwa, Kanchou. You asked to see me?
I thought I could introduce you to something.
Oh, dare desu ka? A member of the crew?
Not who, but what. I've acquired a chessboard recently, and...
Gomenasai, I don't mean to interrupt, but I have no interest in playing it.

Fields.MenuText: You haven't even tried it.
It's fun once you learn it.
... Okay.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't need to try such trivial Western games.
I can think of a hundred other fun things to do.
Thank you for not pressing the issue.
Very well, then... please, take your leave.
Oh, I... Yes, Kanchou.
A battle is upon us.
@BATTLE
I would like to apologize for my behavior earlier. It was inappropriate of me.
It's quite all right.
It was not all right. I rejected your offer and failed to come up with an alternative.
You haven't even tried chess. Why are you so sure you wouldn’t enjoy it? Just because it’s a Western game?
I don't even enjoy speaking English. I’ve no doubt I’d find chess to be a joyless experience.
Well then, what alternative do you propose?
Have you ever played shōgi, Kanchou?

Fields.MenuText: It's the same concept as chess, right?
I've never heard of it.
You'd like to play that instead?

Fields.DialogueText: It's not. It’s far superior.
Then I shall teach you! I believe it's similar... in some ways...  to chess.
I would if you don't mind.
Then take out the board. Let's play.
This will be a far better experience for us both than playing chess would have been. I assure you.
Very well. I hope you’re ready for a challenge. I’m not about to let you push me around, no matter how many times you’ve played this game.
You should know that I never back down from a challenge.
I'm well aware.
Then let's see if you can’t show me some skills.
A battle is upon us.
@BATTLE
Can we stop playing?
Dōshite desu ka? Are four losses in a row too much for you to handle?

Fields.MenuText: I'm tired.
Let's just say that I clearly need to step back and re-examine your strategies.
I'm sick of you bragging so much.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm tired of you trying to give up so much.
Evidently.
You were the one shouting earlier when you thought you'd gained the upper hand.
Chess is sounding more and more appealing with each passing minute.
If you were winning, I think you'd say otherwise.
Very well. If I win this next game, I will stay for another hour.
Thank you, Kanchou. Five wins is much more satisfying, anyway.
A battle is upon us.
@BATTLE
Why do the men keep using forks when they eat? Naze desu ka?
... I'm sorry? What seems to be the problem?
Those are soldiers from Nippon, the greatest civilization on the Earth! They should be using chopsticks, not western utensils!
Just because they don't use chopsticks doesn't mean they don't know how. Spoons and forks are just more convenient and faster to use.
Demo... that's not our way.

Fields.MenuText: If you look around, there *are* sailors using waribashi. But if these men find a knife and fork more convenient, it's their choice.
I don't know what you want me to do.
We can't have everything, Kamikaze.

Fields.DialogueText: I am a Japanese ship. Shouldn't my culture mean something?
We can try.
They know what life is like back home. But this is a matter of war forcing us to change how we live.
Our way of life isn't something we can sacrifice. If it were, what would we be fighting for?
As I thought.
Boxes of fifty! How many times do I need to remind everyone how to store these bullets properly?
Kamikaze!
Hai! What is it, Kanchou?
See me after the battle.
@BATTLE
I'm concerned about how you talk to the crew. I understand you have standards that you feel aren't being met, but...
It is not my fault that they cannot listen to orders.
And how does insulting non-Japanese members of the crew help?
This behavior further distances yourself from the crew. There should be trust between you, not division.
What do you think is the best solution, then?

Fields.MenuText: Leave giving the orders to me.
Approach the situation with a more positive attitude.
Show them how to do their job instead of telling them.

Fields.DialogueText: I am the one carrying everyone.
Do you really think that will work?
Kāsan ja nai. I'm not anyone's mother.
If you continue to think they're being lazy and selfish, this problem will only continue.
Thinking that they're not doing anything wrong is also a problem.
Then let me know if you have a problem with their behavior. I will address it with them.
... Very well. I'm sorry.
It's fine. Just don't do it again.
If you were all of the Nippon Kaigun, I wouldn't have to...
Evasive maneuvers, Kamikaze!
I can hold our offensive, Kanchou! We're almost there!
Oh, for the love of--!
@BATTLE
Are you going to regularly disregard my orders?
Kachimashita yo. We won, did we not?

Fields.MenuText: What if we didn't?
You can't disobey my orders.
Yes, and thank you for helping us defeat the Morganas.

Fields.DialogueText: But we did.
I thought what I was doing would be best.
Dō itashimashite. You're welcome.
I will be the judge of what the best course of action is.
You know that I never...
This isn't a game. You don't get to clear the board if you make a mistake and start over.
I understand that you don't let challenges hinder you, but you need to know when to back down.
... I understand. Thank you, Kanchou.
Now please, listen to what I have to say.
A battle is upon us.
@BATTLE
Shitsurei shimasu. May we discuss this last battle?
Of course. And I would also like to discuss our working relationship.
Oh?
After recent events, I think we need to look to the future and predict how our time together will pan out.
How do you think we'll fare?

Fields.MenuText: I can only hope for the best.
I don't know.
I believe we'll manage.

Fields.DialogueText: But what is the ''best?''
You don't have hope?
I hope so.
We should set some standard rules between us.
Such as?
You need to listen when I deliver orders. You're a brave warrior, but sometimes you go in with such fervor that you risk our safety.
You don't trust my skills?
I don't want to regret trusting them.
Have they let you down so far? Yokatta desu ka?
They've been satisfactory, and you deserve all the recognition for them. I wish, though, that you were more flexible. Not just with me - with everyone.
But...
We do have our traditions, but there's always more than one way of getting something done.
There's a whole world out there, and while Japan is surely great, that doesn't mean we can't appreciate aspects of other cultures.
... I see.
Am I clear?
Hai. Arigatō gozaimasu, Kanchou.
A battle is upon us.
@BATTLE
You told me earlier that there's a whole world out there.
I did. What about it?
But you agree with me that Nippon is the pinnacle of civilization.
I never said that. Where are you going with this conversation?
May I teach the crew about my culture?

Fields.MenuText: That would be fine.
Hm... I'm not sure.
Why?

Fields.DialogueText: You don't have any questions about this?
It's important that the crew understands the culture of Japan if they're to understand me.
I want them to know where I come from.
I trust that it won't get... too out of hand.
They should enjoy learning about Japanese traditions. They'll learn to respect our way of life.
They're already fighting for Nippon, are they not? The Protection Force fights for every nation.
But are they willing to die for Nippon?
They're willing to die for their loved ones, wherever they are, I'm sure.
If only they could successfully store munitions.
Heh.
Wakarimasu. I hope not to disappoint, Kanchou.
All right, go ahead. But I'd advise you to make sure it doesn't feel like a punishment. Make people want to learn, don't just tell them they should.
Katakana was developed during the Heian jidai by Buddhist monks. They were...
Only used by men originally, but that has since changed.
It seems you are aware of the history of the Japanese writing system.
It's common knowledge, more or less. But do you think the subject might be a bit... dry for most of the crew?
This is an essential part of the history of my civilization.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not sure it's the most exciting way to introduce your civilization, though.
True, but it's not very dramatic.
Oh, I agree.

Fields.DialogueText: Nonetheless, I will still discuss it.
What does that have to do with anything?
But?
I just think it's a very specialized point of entry into Japanese culture. If you want to interest the foreign crew, you might want to start with something more... dynamic.
That doesn't discourage me from... We must end this discussion.
Why now?
Morganas are inbound.
@BATTLE
A battle is upon us.
@BATTLE
Shitsurei shimasu. Did you want to deliver a report on the latest battle, Kanchou?
Something else, actually.
What is it?
The crew have been coming to me after your... mandatory lessons on Japanese culture.
The Japanese crew members are already aware of what you're telling them, and the others have no interest in the subject.
Sugoi. They're unbelievably ungrateful.

Fields.MenuText: They didn't ask you to do this.
I'm sorry.
They weren't as open to these teachings as I was.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I did, for their sake!
Your pity doesn't change what happened.
I don't believe you were as open as you could have been.
If you take this personally, it's going to be harder to learn from it.
Kamikaze...
Don't say another word, Kanchou. I'll take my leave.
We haven't spoken to one another in a while.
Haven't we?
Would you please meet me in my quarters after this battle?
Hai, I will see you afterward.
@BATTLE
Hayaku hanashite kudasai. I would like to rest.

Fields.MenuText: You normally don't rest immediately after battles.
That's... new.
That sounds like an excuse.

Fields.DialogueText: As of late, I have.
There've been changes all around.
I’d appreciate it if you would take me at my word.
I should have said this before, but...
And, I appreciate how much effort you expended. You're an inspiration.
Kanchou...
Would you like to play shōgi?
I don't know what you hope to accomplish with...
I think I can beat you, finally.
... I doubt it.
Thank you for taking the time to teach others about your culture. For those not from Japan, especially, I feel it was probably good for them to hear.
A battle is upon us.
@BATTLE
Check your king!
And, after seven losses in a row, that is one win for me.
Omedetō gozaimasu, Kanchou. I'm proud you've come so far.

Fields.MenuText: No need to patronize me.
My sensei taught me well.
I've been practicing strategies since our last set of games.

Fields.DialogueText: No, I honestly congratulate you.
... I appreciate that.
Well, it's finally paid off.
Will you finally try chess?
... If you can beat me again, I will play a game of chess.
Well, in eight more games, I'll set up a new board.
I'm almost looking forward to that.
You owe me one game of chess later.
... Hai.
You said you've never backed down from a challenge.
I never will.
@BATTLE
Pawns in chess can move one or two spaces forward from their initial position, and only once after making their first move.
Similar to the pawns in shōgi.
The bishops can move any number of spaces in a diagonal direction from a given position.
Similar to the bishops in shōgi...
The rooks can move any number of spaces in an orthogonal direction from a given position.
Yes, yes, just like the rooks in shōgi.
Do you see the point I'm trying to make?
The concepts of these two games are very similar.

Fields.MenuText: Thank you for agreeing to try this.
Japan's culture is rich, but that doesn't mean you shouldn't welcome others.
Realize anything else?

Fields.DialogueText: I want to prove that I can, occasionally, be open-minded...
I... I understand, now.
That, because this is so similar, I'll most likely win.
Well, are you ready to play?
Are you ready to lose?
Ganbatte, Nagano no Kami.
A battle is upon us.
@BATTLE
May I ask a favor of you, Kanchou?
I'm assuming this isn't about a report of this battle.
I'd like you to learn tsuzumi.
The drum? Why are you asking me, of all the people on this ship?
If they see you taking the initiative to appreciate Japanese culture, I think the crew will try better as well.

Fields.MenuText: I'll do it.
I need to think about it.
I don't know if I'd be very interested.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Kanchou!
Please, Kanchou.
I won't... brag as much during our tsuzumi lessons as I did with shōgi.
Hai, hai, when will we start?
Why not right now?
Warui desu! How many times do I have to ask for the ammunition to be stored properly? We're going to spend time practicing this afterward!
Kanchou...
You will all listen to Kamikaze's lecture on proper storage! If this problem isn't solved within the next week, I will make your lives markedly more difficult.
I... I appreciate your support.
Meet me later, please. Atte kudasai.
@BATTLE
Kanchou?
Thank you for meeting me. I want to apologize for not taking this action earlier.
I'm just glad you did. What did you want to discuss?
Your need to communicate effectively and not angrily.
What do you mean?

Fields.MenuText: Stop yelling at the crew. It's not your job.
You need to teach the crew how you want a job done if you want it done well. They learn best through instruction.
Practice coming to me if you have problems.

Fields.DialogueText: Hai. It is yours.
I... Okay.
I want to prove that I can be a leader as well.
You're an example to the other Belles in the Imperial Japanese Navy. You could be one to the crew as well, but it will require more patience on your part.
Work with me, and I think, together, we can help the crew to improve.
I would enjoy that. Thank you, Kanchou.
Of course. Now, let’s get to work.
Yes, Kanchou.
Careful, Kamikaze. I am still your superior officer.
My apologies, Kanchou.
And if the crew is hesitant to follow your directions...
Assert my authority and come to you.
Perfect. I think we’re going to see improvements from this point forward.
I have hope as well.

Fields.MenuText: We can overcome anything.
Don't expect it to work immediately.
I believe we can change for each other.

Fields.DialogueText: I... I agree.
No, I only expect us to try our best.
Yes, I'd like that.
Now, let's take these Morganas.
Hai, fukoku kyōhei!
@BATTLE
A battle is upon us.
@BATTLE
I have something for you.
You shouldn't have, Kamikaze.
I wanted to. And, while this is mainly a Buddhist practice, I felt like you should have one.
A daruma?
You're supposed to fill in one eye on the doll and make a wish. When it comes true, you fill in the other eye.

Fields.MenuText: I think I'll wish for...
I'm not sure since I only get one.
I don't know what to say.

Fields.DialogueText: Shizuka nee. You aren't supposed to tell me.
Make sure it's something you'll want later.
Don't talk. Just draw.
All right, all right...
It can be a wish or a goal you have.
That makes for even more options.
Well, I hope you can think of one.
I'm sure, I can think of... something.
No rush, but before the war ends would be ideal.
I know what to wish for, now. Hopefully, you can be here with me when it comes true.
I hope so too.
A battle is upon us.
@BATTLE
I scolded some of the crew... somewhat harshly...  for improper torpedo handling. I'll do better in the future.
Old habits die hard, but at least you're aware.
I appreciate your flexibility.

Fields.MenuText: I trust you'll show progress.
I'm in a good mood from this victory.
Please don't let it happen again.

Fields.DialogueText: Arigatō gozaimasu.
I'm thankful I caught you at a good time, then.
Gomenasai. It won't.
I expect us to try our best as well, Kamikaze. And I'm happy we think the same way about this.
Everything came together well.
And the battle was won. So, all in all, I’m happy.
Would you care to show me how you've improved on the tsuzumi later?
I think I would have preferred to learn taikō.
But you didn't. Will you show me, then?

Fields.MenuText: I suppose.
It doesn't seem I have a choice.
I'm as good playing tsuzumi as I am playing shōgi.

Fields.DialogueText: I look forward to it.
No, you do not.
Play the same song fifty times and it will sound adequate.
@BATTLE
That was...
My apologies, Kamikaze, I do try to practice the tsuzumi, but I’m sure my performance probably wasn’t up to your...
You were fantastic, Kanchou.
Oh? Well... in that case, my sensei taught me well.
A battle is upon us.
@BATTLE
Over-ripe sushi, The Master is full of regret.
Is this your way of telling me the mess hall’s meals aren’t up to snuff?
It's a haiku by Yosa Buson.

Fields.MenuText: I've never heard of him.
When will you recite one of your own works?
From the Meiji era?

Fields.DialogueText: He's one of the most famous poets in history!
When the time is more appropriate.
Chigau. He's from the Edo era.
I think I'd prefer your works to his.
You've yet to hear any of them.
Regardless, I think yours would be more enlightening.
You know I’m a private person, Kanchou.
I know. And I’d never push you to share your poetry before you were ready. But I hope, one day, you’ll share with me.
One day? Maybe. Just maybe.
A battle is upon us.
@BATTLE
Another victory against the Morganas.
I'd brag, but I don't want to expect that we'll defeat everyone in our path.
Even if we do one day fall in battle, know that it's been an honor to work with you, Kami of the Fleet.
As it has with you, Kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: I don't have many friends as dedicated as you.
I hope this partnership will last a lifetime.

Fields.DialogueText: I've been led by many, but none are as brave as you.
I wouldn't have it any other way.
You've taught me so much, and given me a better understanding of Japan as a whole.
It's what I wanted.
I'm excited to see what the world has in store for us.
More games like chess?
Perhaps a game which will be kinder to me than it is to you, for once.
I don't think such a game exists.
I picked up a new shōgi board when we last made port. Would you be interested in seeing it?
You should've started the conversation with that.
Shall we?
Hai, prepare to lose yet again.
